docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Roland W. Burris, Democrat of Illinois, does not get a whole lot of attention in the Capitol. He arrived in the Senate under a cloud, appointed by the soon-to-be impeached Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, and said he would not run in 2010 to keep his seat. But with Senate Democrats needing 60 votes to overcome a likely Republican filibuster on the major health care legislation, there is not a single Democratic vote to spare, not even one by a fill-in, lame-duck junior senator from Illinois.

headline.kicker: A FILL-IN WITH A FULL VOTE

docs.abstract: Sen Roland W Burris warns colleagues that he will not support health care bill without government-run insurance plan to compete with private insurers; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Senator Roland W. Burris, Democrat of Illinois, does not get a whole lot of attention in the Capitol. He arrived in the Senate under a cloud, appointed by the soon-to-be impeached Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, and said he would not run in 2010 to keep his...

docs.lead_paragraph: Experts generally agree on the need to change how doctors and hospitals are paid in this country. Currently, most are reimbursed for every service they provide. But this so-called fee-for-service payment system does do little to encourage cost control or -- because, typically, no single health care provider is in charge -- to coordinate patient care effectively. Now a new approach that aims to do a better job of ''aligning incentives,'' as the wonks like to say, has grabbed the attention of policy experts and legislators. They talk about the ''accountable care organization,'' an approach in which doctors and hospitals agree to take joint responsibility for helping patients get well, or keeping them healthy in the first place, and to share in any financial benefits that result.
docs.abstract: Health care legislation pending in Senate Finance Committee and in House would create pilot accountable-care programs under Medicare; doctors and hospitals would agree to take joint responsibility for helping patients get well, or keeping them healthy in first place, and to share in financial benefits that result; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Experts generally agree on the need to change how doctors and hospitals are paid in this country. Currently, most are reimbursed for every service they provide. But this so-called fee-for-service payment system does do little to encourage cost...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Times's new ''Health Care Conversations'' online forum continues to generate reader discussion about Washington's efforts to change the health system. Since the forum began Oct. 1, the topic drawing the most traffic has been ''The Public Option,'' with hundreds of readers posting comments on the idea of a government-run insurance plan that would compete with private insurers.
docs.abstract: Reader comments on New York Times's Health Care Conversations online forum tend to be heavily in support of government-run insurance plan that would compete with private insurers; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With all the attention on the swine flu pandemic, another influenza problem has arisen, almost overlooked. Supplies of the vaccine for the garden-variety seasonal flu have run short. Public health departments across the country have had to cancel vaccination clinics. Doctors have had to turn away patients. And consumers have had to make extra efforts to get immunized.

headline.main: Supplies of Regular Flu Vaccine Run Short in Places, but Impact Is Played Down

docs.abstract: Public health officials and vaccine manufacturers say that supplies of vaccine for garden-variety seasonal flu have run short; say that shortfall is temporary and was caused in part by need to shift resources to swine flu vaccine (M)
docs.snippet: With all the attention on swine flu, supplies of the vaccine for garden-variety seasonal flu have run short.
